clean_story:
Archetypes. Libido.

 Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung, two towering figures in psychology, diverged in their theoretical perspectives, notably on the nature of the unconscious.  Freud emphasized the sexual basis of the unconscious, positing that repressed desires, particularly sexual ones, were the primary drivers of human behavior.  Jung, however, expanded the concept to include a collective unconscious, a shared reservoir of experiences and archetypes across humanity.   Another point of contention was the role of libido.  Freud viewed libido strictly as sexual energy, a central element in his psychoanalytic theory.  Jung disagreed, broadening the term to encompass all life energy, which he believed could manifest in various forms beyond sexuality.  This fundamental difference shaped their respective approaches to understanding the psyche.   Their disagreement also touched on the interpretation of dreams.  Freud saw dreams as wish fulfillments, primarily linked to repressed desires.  Jung, on the other hand, considered dreams as a means of communication from the unconscious, offering insights into personal and universal truths.  This distinction highlighted their divergent views on the purpose and meaning of dreams.   The Jung-Freud disagreement ultimately led to a split, with Jung establishing his own school of thought, Analytical Psychology.  Their intellectual rift had lasting impacts on the field, influencing generations of psychologists.  Three related subjects are the collective unconscious, dream analysis, and the evolution of psychoanalytic theory.
